resources.string: Maintaining good communication is the most effeective way to protect your kid.
Pay attention to changes in your child’s behavior
Make it rewarding for children to develop the habit of telling you about what happens at school each day.
Start from asking specific questions in a cheerful way that goes beyond: “How was school today?”
Tell children clearly,and often, “You have the right to feel safe and respected at school and the responsibility to act safely, respectfully towards others.
If you are upset, your children would be upset too. They would try to protect you by not telling the problems In their life
Start with asking a couple of specific questions each day with curiosity rather than anxiety
Questions like: “What games did you play at recess? Did the class guinea pig do anything silly?”
And then question like: “Do you have any interesting stories to tell me about what people said or did?”
Keep going deeper on very question you ask
Questions like this helps: “I saw this happen/heard about this happening. It looked/sounded like it might be unpleasant for you. Can you tell me more about it?”
Stay respectful, loving, and peaceful when you listen to their answers
Instead of jumping to conclusions or making assumptions, take time to get the whole story
Ask questions to your child in a calm, reassuring way and listen to the answers
